text:
"open to remote" does send up some red flags for me - not so much on the "ability to move into leadership" because I imagine if you're motivated enough and effective enough in your role to even be in the running for leadership, that will come through from wherever.

But what "open to remote" says to me is that the company isn't actively thinking about how to support remote employees or investing in work- and communication-flows that make that kind of work successful. So to me it sounds like a lot of added friction and unsolved problems that any remote employee would have to fight against.

Hopefully we'll see less and less "open to remote" and more and more "remote-first" or "location agnostic" opportunities in this brave new post-Covid world we seem to be teeing up for.

text:
I agree it’s a red flag and signals they likely don’t have a formal work from home policy in place! Someone joining and asking to work remotely might be more of a test and it’s not always great to be an experiment haha. 

Without intention, remote work tends to fall flat as a natural hierarchy builds with office employees at the top and remote workers at the bottom. 

I would have reservations about joining a team where other team members were not remote and the company didn’t operate in a way that’s inclusive of remote employees (e.g. remote-first, asynchronous-first).
